To send a crew of **three astronauts** into a 400 km orbit for a three-day mission.
What is the name of the astronaut training facility being built by ISRO?
The **Astronaut Training Facility** in Bengaluru.
What is the name of the first Indian to go to space?
**Rakesh Sharma**, in 1984.
What was the name of the spacecraft Rakesh Sharma used?
**Soyuz T-11**.
What is ISRO's planned mission to study the Sun?
**Aditya-L1**.
What is the main objective of the Aditya-L1 mission?
To study the **solar corona** and solar flares.
What is ISRO's planned mission to Venus?
**Shukrayaan-1**.
What is the name of the joint ISRO-NASA Earth observation mission?
**NISAR** (NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar).
What is the objective of the NISAR mission?
To measure changes in Earth's ecosystems, ice mass, and land surface.
What is the main fuel used in the PSLV's first stage?
**Solid fuel** (a composite propellant).
What type of engine powers the upper stage of the GSLV?
A **cryogenic engine**.
What is a cryogenic engine?
An engine that uses propellants at extremely low temperatures, like liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen.
What is the significance of the Vikas engine?
It is a liquid-fueled rocket engine used in both the **PSLV and GSLV**.
What is the name of ISRO's launch vehicle that uses a semi-cryogenic engine?
**GSLV Mk-III**.
Which country did ISRO collaborate with for the Chandrayaan-1 mission?
The **United States**, with NASA's instruments.
What is the name of the joint ISRO-France satellite mission for climate studies?
**Megha-Tropiques**.
What is a major international achievement of the PSLV?
It has launched satellites for **more than 30 countries**.
What is the name of ISRO's commercial arm?
**Antrix Corporation** and **NewSpace India Limited (NSIL)**.
What is the purpose of NSIL?
To be the primary interface for ISRO's commercial activities.
How has ISRO contributed to disaster management in India?
Through the use of **satellite imagery** for early warnings and damage assessment.
What is the role of ISRO in education?
It provides satellite communication for **distance education** and research.
How is ISRO's technology used in agriculture?
For **crop yield estimation** and monitoring of soil and water resources.
What is ISRO's role in weather forecasting?
It provides real-time data from its meteorological satellites, like the **INSAT** series.
What is the name of the first full-fledged meteorological satellite launched by ISRO?
**Kalpana-1**.
What is the main launch vehicle ISRO uses for low-Earth orbit missions?
The **Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV)**.
What does the 'XL' variant of the PSLV signify?
It is a more powerful version with extended strap-on boosters.
What is the GSLV Mark III's new operational name?
The **LVM3** (Launch Vehicle Mark 3).
What is a semi-cryogenic engine?
An engine that uses a combination of liquid kerosene and liquid oxygen as propellants.
What is the purpose of ISRO's Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV)?
To provide a low-cost, on-demand launch capability for **smaller payloads**.
What is the primary function of the **RISAT** series of satellites?
**Radar imaging** for surveillance and all-weather Earth observation.
Which satellite is used for cartography and land mapping?
The **Cartosat** series of satellites.
What does the **Oceansat** series of satellites primarily study?
**Oceanographic** and atmospheric parameters.
What is the purpose of the **EOS** series of satellites?
They are a new series of **Earth Observation Satellites**.
What is the main objective of the jointly developed **NISAR** mission with NASA?
To study land and ice deformation and ecosystem changes using a dual-frequency radar.
What is the full form of **NavIC**?
**Navigation with Indian Constellation**.
How many satellites are currently in the NavIC constellation?
There are **11** satellites in orbit as of August 2025.
What is the purpose of the **GSAT** series?
They are **Geostationary Communication Satellites** for broadcasting and communication.
What is the main objective of the **INSAT** series?
Providing satellite services for communication, weather forecasting, and broadcasting.
What is the name of ISRO's first satellite dedicated to educational services?
**EDUSAT** (GSAT-3).
What was the name of the lander for the **Chandrayaan-3** mission?
**Vikram**.
What was the name of the rover for the **Chandrayaan-3** mission?
**Pragyan**.
What was the primary objective of the **Chandrayaan-3** mission?
To demonstrate a safe and soft landing on the lunar surface.
What was the most significant finding of the **Chandrayaan-3** rover?
The confirmation of the presence of **sulfur** and other elements near the lunar south pole.
What is the name of ISRO's first mission to the Sun?
**Aditya-L1**.
What is the name of India's human spaceflight program?
**Gaganyaan**.
What is the primary goal of the Gaganyaan mission?
To send a crew of three astronauts into a **400 km orbit** for a three-day mission.
What is the name of the humanoid robot developed for the Gaganyaan mission?
**Vyommitra**.
When is the first uncrewed Gaganyaan test flight scheduled for?
The first uncrewed test flight is targeted for **December 2025**.
What is the name of ISRO's planned mission to Venus?
**Shukrayaan-1**.
What is ISRO's commercial arm responsible for launching satellites for other countries?
**NewSpace India Limited (NSIL)**.
What is the name of the joint ISRO-NASA Earth observation satellite mission?
**NISAR** (NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar).
What does the **L-band** radar in NISAR help to study?
It can penetrate forest canopies and soil to detect changes in **biomass** and land surfaces.
What does the **S-band** radar in NISAR help to study?
It is useful for monitoring **crop health** and soil moisture.
What is ISRO's collaboration with France on for climate studies?
The **Megha-Tropiques** and **SARAL** missions.
What type of engine is used in the final stage of the GSLV Mk III?
A **cryogenic engine**.
What is the main challenge in developing a cryogenic engine?
It requires handling propellants like liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen at **extremely low temperatures**.
What is the name of ISRO's reusable launch vehicle technology demonstrator?
The **RLV-TD**.
What is the name of the liquid-fueled engine used in both PSLV and GSLV?
The **Vikas engine**.
What is a **SCRAMJET** engine, and what is its purpose in ISRO's research?
A SCRAMJET engine is an air-breathing propulsion system being developed for future reusable launch vehicles.
What was the primary instrument on the **Aditya-L1** mission?
The **Visible Emission Line Coronagraph (VELC)** to study the Sun's corona.
What was one of the instruments on the **Chandrayaan-3** lander?
The **Instrument for Lunar Seismic Activity (ILSA)**.
What was the purpose of the **Pragyan** rover's **LIBS** payload?
To determine the **elemental composition** of the lunar surface.
What is the primary purpose of the **XPoSat** mission?
To study the **polarization of X-rays** from celestial sources.
What is the name of the scientific instrument on the **Chandrayaan-3** propulsion module that studied Earth?
The **Spectro-polarimetry of Habitable Planet Earth (SHAPE)** payload.
How does ISRO help with disaster management?
It provides satellite imagery for **early warnings** of cyclones and floods.
What is the role of ISRO in education and telemedicine?
It provides satellite services for **distance education** and healthcare.
How does ISRO support Indian farmers?
Through remote sensing for **crop health monitoring** and water resource management.
What is the purpose of the **Metsat** series of satellites?
To provide meteorological data for **weather forecasting**.
How did ISRO assist the fishing community?
By providing **satellite data** on potential fishing zones.
What is ISRO's plan for a future lunar mission to bring back samples?
**Chandrayaan-4**, a lunar sample return mission.
What is the plan for an Indian space station?
The development of a **five-module space station** with the first module planned for launch in 2028.
What is the name of ISRO's latest rocket, which is a private-sector built launch vehicle?
**PSLV N1**, built by HAL and L&T.
What is the purpose of the **SPADEX** mission?
It's a technology demonstration mission for **in-space docking**.
When is the first uncrewed orbital flight of the Gaganyaan mission scheduled for?
The first uncrewed orbital flight (G1) is targeted for the **end of 2025**.
What does BARC stand for?
**Bhabha Atomic Research Centre**.
Who founded BARC?
**Dr. Homi J. Bhabha**.
What was BARC's original name?
**Atomic Energy Establishment, Trombay** (AEET).
When was BARC established?
When was it renamed to BARC?
It was renamed after Dr. Bhabha's death in **1966**.
What was India's first nuclear research reactor?
**Apsara**, commissioned in 1956.
What is the name of the first indigenously designed and built nuclear reactor in India?
**Dhruva**.
What type of reactor is Dhruva?
A **heavy water moderated** research reactor.
What is the purpose of the Dhruva reactor?
It is used for producing **radioisotopes** and research.
What is the name of the first pressurized heavy water reactor (PHWR) prototype in India?
**Cirus**, a reactor gifted by Canada.
What was BARC's role in the Pokhran-I nuclear tests?
BARC developed the **fission device** used in the tests.
What was the codename for the Pokhran-I tests?
**Smiling Buddha**.
When did the Pokhran-I tests take place?
What was BARC's role in the Pokhran-II tests?
BARC was the lead organization in developing the **nuclear devices**.
What was the codename for the Pokhran-II tests?
**Operation Shakti**.
What is the primary area of research at BARC?
**Nuclear science** and its applications for peaceful purposes.
Name two major areas of research at BARC.
**Nuclear power** and **radioisotope production**.
What is BARC's contribution to agriculture?
It has developed new crop **mutant varieties** with improved yield and resistance.
What is BARC's contribution to medicine?
It produces a wide range of **radioisotopes** for medical diagnosis and therapy.
What is BARC's contribution to water management?
It has developed technology for **desalination** and water purification.
Who was the founder of India's nuclear program?
**Dr. Homi J. Bhabha**.
Where is BARC's main campus located?
**Trombay**, in Mumbai, Maharashtra.
What is the name of BARC's first Director after it was renamed?
**Dr. Raja Ramanna**.
Who was the director of BARC during the Pokhran-II tests?
**Dr. R. Chidambaram**.
What is the name of the main research campus in Mumbai?
The **Trombay campus**.
What is the primary goal of BARC's nuclear safety protocol?
To ensure **zero harm** to people and the environment.
What is a key safety measure in BARC's reactors?
The use of multiple layers of **containment**.
What is BARC's role in radioactive waste management?
It has developed and implemented technologies for the **safe disposal** of nuclear waste.
What is the name of the organization that regulates nuclear safety in India?
The **Atomic Energy Regulatory Board** (AERB).
How does BARC handle nuclear security?
It follows strict **international guidelines** and protocols to prevent theft or sabotage.
What is a major technological spin-off from BARC?
The development of **desalination plants** for coastal regions.
How has BARC contributed to the food industry?
By developing technology for **food preservation** and irradiation.
What is BARC's contribution to industrial radiography?
It has developed and supplied **gamma cameras** and sources for non-destructive testing.
What is a major contribution of BARC to material science?
Research on **new materials** for use in nuclear reactors and other applications.
What is BARC's contribution to robotics?
The development of **remote-handling systems** for hazardous environments.
What is the name of the three-stage nuclear power program developed by BARC?
The **three-stage nuclear program**.
What is the primary fuel used in the first stage of the program?
**Natural Uranium** in Pressurized Heavy Water Reactors.
What is the primary fuel used in the second stage of the program?
**Plutonium-239** in Fast Breeder Reactors.
What is the primary fuel used in the third stage of the program?
**Thorium-232** in advanced heavy water reactors.
Why is India focusing on thorium?
India has vast reserves of **thorium**.
What is the name of BARC's reactor that is used for neutron beam research?
**Dhruva**.
What is the name of BARC's low-power swimming pool-type reactor?
**Apsara**.
What is the name of BARC's reactor that was shut down in 2010?
**Cirus**.
What is the name of the new high-flux research reactor being built at BARC?
**Apsara-U**, a modernized version of Apsara.
What is the primary use of BARC's research reactors?
**Radioisotope production** for medicine, industry, and research.
How does BARC contribute to India's national security?
By providing scientific and technical support to India's **nuclear deterrence program**.
What is the name of the organization that oversees the nuclear weapons program in India?
The **Department of Atomic Energy** (DAE).
What is BARC's role in nuclear non-proliferation?
It adheres to all **international protocols** for peaceful use of nuclear technology.
What is the purpose of BARC's research on plutonium?
To support the **second stage** of India's nuclear power program.
How does BARC's work relate to India's energy security?
It is developing a technology to ensure **long-term energy security** through its three-stage program.
What is a poem?
A poem is a piece of writing that expresses feelings, ideas, or experiences using a distinctive style and rhythm.
What is a stanza?
A stanza is a group of lines forming the basic recurring metrical unit in a poem; it's a "verse" of a poem.
What is a line in poetry?
A line is a unit of language into which a poem is divided.
What is rhythm in poetry?
Rhythm is the pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables in a line of poetry.
What is meter?
Meter is a specific pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables that creates a regular rhythm.
What is a sonnet?
A sonnet is a 14-line poem, typically with a strict rhyme scheme and meter, often iambic pentameter.
What is a haiku?
A haiku is a Japanese poetic form with three lines, following a 5, 7, 5 syllable pattern.
What is a limerick?
A limerick is a five-line, humorous poem with a distinct AABBA rhyme scheme.
What is free verse?
Free verse is a poetic form that does not follow a regular rhythm, meter, or rhyme scheme.
What is a ballad?
A ballad is a narrative poem, often set to music, that tells a story.
What is alliteration?
Alliteration is the repetition of the same initial consonant sound in a series of words.
What is assonance?
Assonance is the repetition of vowel sounds within nearby words.
What is consonance?
Consonance is the repetition of consonant sounds within words or at the end of words.
What is rhyme?
Rhyme is the repetition of similar sounds in the final stressed syllables of words.
What is onomatopoeia?
Onomatopoeia is a word that imitates the natural sound of a thing, like "buzz" or "hiss."
What is a metaphor?
A metaphor is a direct comparison between two unlike things without using "like" or "as."
What is a simile?
A simile is a comparison between two unlike things using "like" or "as."
What is personification?
Personification is a literary device where human qualities are given to inanimate objects or abstract ideas.
What is hyperbole?
Hyperbole is an exaggeration used for emphasis or effect.
What is an idiom?
An idiom is a phrase or expression that has a figurative meaning different from its literal meaning.
What is imagery?
Imagery is the use of vivid and descriptive language to create a mental picture for the reader.
What is symbolism?
Symbolism is the use of an object or a word to represent an abstract idea.
What is mood in poetry?
Mood is the feeling or atmosphere that the poet creates for the reader.
What is tone?
Tone is the attitude of the writer toward the subject or audience.
What is a motif?
A motif is a recurring element, idea, or subject in a poem that often has symbolic significance.
What is an epic poem?
An epic poem is a long, narrative poem that tells the story of a heroic figure.
What is a lyric poem?
A lyric poem is a short poem that expresses a poet's personal feelings and emotions.
What is a dramatic monologue?
A dramatic monologue is a poem in the form of a speech by an imagined person, revealing their character.
What is an ode?
An ode is a lyric poem that is serious and thoughtful in tone, and often celebrates a person or event.
What is a villanelle?
A villanelle is a 19-line poem with five tercets and a final quatrain, with a strict rhyme scheme and two repeating refrains.
What is enjambment?
Enjambment is the continuation of a sentence or clause across a line break without a pause.
What is caesura?
Caesura is a pause or break in the middle of a line of poetry, often marked by punctuation.
What is an anaphora?
An anaphora is the repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning of successive clauses.
What is a refrain?
A refrain is a repeated line or phrase in a poem, often at the end of a stanza.
What is inversion?
Inversion is the reversal of the normal word order in a sentence.
What is a couplet?
A couplet is a pair of rhyming lines in a poem.
What is a quatrain?
A quatrain is a stanza of four lines, especially one having a strict rhyme scheme.
What is a sestet?
A sestet is the final six lines of a sonnet, or a stanza of six lines.
What is a perfect rhyme?
A perfect rhyme is when the final stressed syllables of two words are identical, like "cat" and "hat."
What is a slant rhyme?
A slant rhyme is a rhyme in which the stressed syllables of ending consonants match, but the preceding vowel sounds do not.
What is iambic pentameter?
Iambic pentameter is a line of poetry with five metrical feet, each consisting of one unstressed syllable followed by a stressed syllable.
What is a foot in poetry?
A foot is a basic unit of meter, consisting of a combination of stressed and unstressed syllables.
What is a trochee?
A trochee is a metrical foot consisting of a stressed syllable followed by an unstressed one.
What is a dactyl?
A dactyl is a metrical foot consisting of one stressed syllable followed by two unstressed syllables.
What is anapest?
Anapest is a metrical foot consisting of two unstressed syllables followed by one stressed syllable.
What is a sestina?
A sestina is a highly structured poem of 39 lines, with six stanzas of six lines each and a three-line envoy.
What is a ghazal?
A ghazal is a lyrical poem, often about love, with rhyming couplets and a refrain.
What is a rondeau?
A rondeau is a 13-line poem with two rhymes and a repeating refrain.
What is an acrostic poem?
An acrostic poem is a poem where the first letter of each line spells out a word or message.
What is an epigram?
An epigram is a short, witty, and often satirical poem or saying.
What is an apostrophe?
An apostrophe is a literary device where a speaker addresses an imaginary person, object, or abstract idea.
What is a paradox?
A paradox is a statement that appears self-contradictory but contains a deeper truth.
What is an oxymoron?
An oxymoron is a figure of speech that combines contradictory words, like "jumbo shrimp."
What is synecdoche?
Synecdoche is a figure of speech where a part of something represents the whole, or vice versa.
What is metonymy?
Metonymy is a figure of speech where a related word or phrase is substituted for the actual word, like "the Crown" for the monarchy.
What is euphony?
Euphony is the use of pleasant, harmonious sounds in a poem, often created by smooth consonants and vowels.
What is cacophony?
Cacophony is the use of harsh, jarring sounds in a poem to create a discordant effect.
What is an internal rhyme?
An internal rhyme is a rhyme that occurs within a single line of poetry.
What is a feminine rhyme?
A feminine rhyme is a rhyme that matches two or more syllables, with the final syllable being unstressed.
What is a masculine rhyme?
A masculine rhyme is a rhyme on a single stressed syllable, like "know" and "flow."
What is a sestet?
A sestet is a six-line stanza.
What is a tercet?
A tercet is a three-line stanza.
What is a septet?
A septet is a seven-line stanza.
What is an octave?
An octave is an eight-line stanza, especially the first eight lines of an Italian sonnet.
What is an heroic couplet?
An heroic couplet is a rhyming pair of lines written in iambic pentameter.
What is a narrative poem?
A narrative poem is a poem that tells a story.
What is a mock epic?
A mock epic is a satirical poem that treats a trivial subject in a grand, epic style.
What is a verse novel?
A verse novel is a type of narrative poetry that tells a story in verse form.
What is a fable?
A fable is a short story, typically with animals as characters, that conveys a moral.
What is a parable?
A parable is a short allegorical story designed to teach a moral or religious lesson.
What is pastoral poetry?
Pastoral poetry deals with the lives of shepherds and the idealization of rural life.
What is an elegy?
An elegy is a mournful or melancholic poem, typically for the dead.
What is a sonnet cycle?
A sonnet cycle is a collection of sonnets on a single theme.
What is a didactic poem?
A didactic poem is a poem intended to teach a lesson or impart knowledge.
What is a dramatic poem?
A dramatic poem is a poem in which one or more characters speak, as in a play.
Who is known as the father of English poetry?
**Geoffrey Chaucer**.
Who is considered the national poet of Scotland?
**Robert Burns**.
Who was a famous American poet known for her unique style and capitalization?
**Emily Dickinson**.
Who was a famous poet of the Romantic era who wrote "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"?
**Samuel Taylor Coleridge**.
Who was a famous poet who wrote "Ode to a Nightingale"?
**John Keats**.
What was the Romanticism movement in poetry?
A movement that emphasized emotion, individualism, and the glorification of nature.
What was the Modernism movement in poetry?
A movement that rejected traditional forms and subject matter, focusing on experimentation and fragmentation.
What was the Imagism movement?
A movement that favored precision of imagery and clear, sharp language.
What was the Beat Generation in poetry?
A post-World War II literary movement that rejected traditional norms and celebrated nonconformity.
What was the Harlem Renaissance?
A literary and cultural movement that celebrated African American identity and culture in the 1920s.
What is an understatement?
An understatement is a figure of speech in which a writer or speaker intentionally makes a situation seem less important than it is.
What is synesthesia?
Synesthesia is a literary device where one sense is described using terms from another, like a "loud color."
What is a pathetic fallacy?
A pathetic fallacy is a type of personification where inanimate objects are given human emotions, especially in nature.
What is internal rhyme?
An internal rhyme is a rhyme that occurs within a single line of poetry.
What is a half rhyme?
A half rhyme is a rhyme in which the final consonants of words are the same, but the vowels are different.
What is a metrical foot?
A metrical foot is a basic unit of meter, consisting of a specific pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables.
What is the famous poem written by Edgar Allan Poe about a raven?
"The Raven."
What is the famous epic poem about a hero's journey home from the Trojan War?
"The Odyssey."
What is the famous poem by William Wordsworth about a host of daffodils?
"The Road Not Taken."
What is the famous poem by Walt Whitman that celebrates the American spirit?
"I Wandered Lonely as a Cloud."
What is a pantoum?
"Song of Myself."
What is the official language of India?
A pantoum is a Malaysian poetic form composed of a series of quatrains where the second and fourth lines of each stanza become the first and third lines of the next.
What script is Hindi written in?
**Hindi** is one of the two official languages of the Union Government of India.
What is a vowel in Hindi?
Hindi is written in the **Devanagari** script.
What is a consonant in Hindi?
A vowel is a "Swar" (**स्वर**), a speech sound made by the passage of air without any obstruction.
How many vowels are there in the Devanagari script?
A consonant is a "Vyanjan" (**व्यंजन**), a sound produced with some obstruction in the vocal tract.
What does "Namaste" (**नमस्ते**) mean?
There are **11** vowels.
How do you say "thank you" in Hindi?
"Namaste" means **hello** or greetings.
How do you say "how are you" in Hindi?
You say "dhanyavad" (**धन्यवाद**).
What does "jaldi" (**जल्दी**) mean?
You say "Aap kaise hain?" (**आप कैसे हैं?**).
What does "pani" (**पानी**) mean?
"Jaldi" means **quickly** or in a hurry.
What is a noun in Hindi?
"Pani" means **water**.
What is a verb in Hindi?
A noun is a "Sangya" (**संज्ञा**), which can be a person, place, or thing.
What are the three main genders in Hindi?
A verb is a "Kriya" (**क्रिया**), a word that expresses an action or state of being.
How do you form a simple present tense sentence?
Hindi has two genders: **masculine** (पुल्लिंग) and **feminine** (स्त्रीलिंग).
How is a question formed in Hindi?
You add the suffix "ta hai" (**ता है**) for masculine and "ti hai" (**ती है**) for feminine to the verb stem.
What is the word for "I" in Hindi?
You add the word "kya" (**क्या**) at the beginning of a sentence.
What is the word for "you" (formal) in Hindi?
The word for "I" is "main" (**मैं**).
What is the word for "he" or "she" in Hindi?
The formal word for "you" is "aap" (**आप**).
What is the word for "we" in Hindi?
The word for "he" or "she" is "vah" (**वह**).
What is the word for "they" in Hindi?
The word for "we" is "hum" (**हम**).
How do you say "one" in Hindi?
The word for "they" is "ve" (**वे**).
How do you say "ten" in Hindi?
"One" is "ek" (**एक**).
How do you say "fifty" in Hindi?
"Ten" is "das" (**दस**).
How do you say "one hundred" in Hindi?
"Fifty" is "pachas" (**पचास**).
How do you say "one thousand" in Hindi?
"One hundred" is "sau" (**सौ**).
What do you call a father in Hindi?
"One thousand" is "hazaar" (**हज़ार**).
What do you call a mother in Hindi?
A father is called "pita" (**पिता**) or "papa" (**पापा**).
What do you call an elder brother?
A mother is called "mata" (**माता**) or "mummy" (**मम्मी**).
What do you call an elder sister?
An elder brother is called "bhaiya" (**भैया**).
What do you call a younger sister?
An elder sister is called "didi" (**दीदी**).
What is the word for "red" in Hindi?
A younger sister is called "behen" (**बहन**).
What is the word for "blue" in Hindi?
The word for "red" is "lal" (**लाल**).
What is the word for "green" in Hindi?
The word for "blue" is "neela" (**नीला**).
What is the word for "yellow" in Hindi?
The word for "green" is "hara" (**हरा**).
What is the word for "black" in Hindi?
The word for "yellow" is "peela" (**पीला**).
How do you say "today" in Hindi?
The word for "black" is "kala" (**काला**).
How do you say "tomorrow" in Hindi?
"Today" is "aaj" (**आज**).
How do you say "yesterday" in Hindi?
"Tomorrow" is "kal" (**कल**).
What is the word for "time" in Hindi?
"Yesterday" is also "kal" (**कल**).
What is the word for "morning" in Hindi?
The word for "time" is "samay" (**समय**).
What does "khana" (**खाना**) mean?
The word for "morning" is "subah" (**सुबह**).
What does "pina" (**पीना**) mean?
"Khana" means **to eat** or food.
What is the word for "rice" in Hindi?
"Pina" means **to drink**.
What is the word for "bread" in Hindi?
The word for "rice" is "chawal" (**चावल**).
What does "chai" (**चाय**) mean?
The word for "bread" is "roti" (**रोटी**).

What does the term "anime" refer to?
Anime refers to a distinctive style of  Japanese animation .
What is a "manga"?
A  manga  is a Japanese comic book or graphic novel that is often the source material for anime.
What is a "shounen" anime?
A  shounen  anime is a genre aimed at a young male audience, often featuring action and adventure.
What is a "shoujo" anime?
A  shoujo  anime is a genre aimed at a young female audience, often focusing on romance and drama.
What is a "seinen" anime?
A  seinen  anime is a genre targeted at adult men, featuring more mature themes.
What is a "josei" anime?
A  josei  anime is a genre targeted at adult women, with more realistic and complex storylines.

The main theme is humanity's struggle for survival against giant humanoids known as  Titans .

Cosplay  is the practice of dressing up as a character from a work of fiction, such as anime.

A  tsundere  is a character who is initially cold or hostile but later reveals a warmer, more affectionate side.
What is a "yandere" character?
A  yandere  is a character who is initially sweet but becomes dangerously obsessive and violent.
What is "kawaii"?
Kawaii  is a Japanese term for "cute."

A  sensei  is a Japanese term for a teacher or master.

An  otaku  is a Japanese term for someone with an obsessive interest in anime, manga, and video games.

A  moe  character is one who evokes feelings of affection, adoration, or protectiveness.

When did World War I begin?
World War I began on July 28, 1914.
What event is widely considered the trigger for the war?
The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary.
Who was the Archduke who was assassinated?
Archduke Franz Ferdinand.
In what city was the Archduke assassinated?
He was assassinated in Sarajevo.
What were the two main alliances in the war called?
The Allied Powers and the Central Powers.
What countries formed the initial Central Powers?
Germany, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Bulgaria.
What countries formed the initial Allied Powers?
France, Britain, Russia, and later the United States.
What was the name of the German war plan to quickly defeat France?
The Schlieffen Plan.
What new type of warfare was characteristic of the Western Front?
Trench warfare.
What was the area between the trenches called?
It was called No Man's Land.
What was the name of the German airship used for bombing raids?
The airship was a Zeppelin.
What was the name of the German submarines?
The submarines were called U-boats.

The Battle of Jutland.

Kaiser Wilhelm II was the leader.

Woodrow Wilson was the President.

The U.S. entered the war in 1917.

Russia left the war.

The Treaty of Versailles.

What is the most common type of cement used worldwide?
The most common type is  Portland cement .
What is the primary purpose of cement in construction?
Cement acts as a  binder or glue  to hold other materials together.
Who is credited with inventing Portland cement?
An English bricklayer named  Joseph Aspdin  patented Portland cement in 1824.
What are the main ingredients of cement?
The main ingredients are  limestone and clay .
What is the difference between cement and concrete?
Cement is an ingredient , while  concrete is the final product  made from cement, water, and aggregates.
What is a key step in the manufacturing of cement?
A key step is heating limestone and clay in a kiln to form  clinker .
What is the world's largest cement company by production capacity?
The world's largest is the  Holcim Group  (formerly LafargeHolcim).
What is the main environmental concern related to cement production?
Cement production is a significant source of  carbon dioxide emissions .
What is the purpose of gypsum in cement?
Gypsum is added to  control the setting time  of the cement.
What is a "fly ash"?
Fly ash is a byproduct of coal-fired power plants used as an  additive to improve concrete properties .
What is Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC) used for?
OPC is used for  general-purpose construction , such as buildings and pavements.
What is White Portland Cement used for?
White Portland cement is used for  architectural and decorative purposes .
What is Portland Pozzolana Cement (PPC) used for?
PPC is ideal for construction in  damp areas and marine environments .
What is Sulfate-Resistant Cement used for?
This cement is used in areas exposed to  sulfate attack , such as in coastal or industrial zones.
What is Rapid-Hardening Cement used for?
Rapid-Hardening Cement is used when  early strength development  is a requirement.
What is Low-Heat Cement used for?
Low-Heat Cement is used for  mass concrete construction , such as dams, to prevent cracking.
What is Blast Furnace Slag Cement used for?
This cement is used in construction where  high durability and sulfate resistance  are needed.
What is High-Alumina Cement used for?
High-Alumina Cement is used for  refractory concrete  that can withstand high temperatures.
What is Masonry Cement used for?
Masonry Cement is used to make  mortar for brickwork and plastering .
What is Oil-Well Cement used for?
This type of cement is used in drilling for oil wells, where it must withstand  high temperatures and pressures .
What is the chemical process that causes cement to harden?
The process is called  hydration , a chemical reaction with water.
What is "unsoundness" in cement?
Unsoundness refers to a cement's tendency to  expand and crack  after it has set.
What is "efflorescence" in cement?
Efflorescence is a white, powdery residue on concrete caused by  salt deposits .
What is the function of lime in cement?
Lime imparts  strength and soundness  to the cement.
What is the function of silica in cement?
Silica imparts  strength  to the cement.
What is the function of alumina in cement?
Alumina imparts a  quick-setting property  to the cement.
What is the function of iron oxide in cement?
Iron oxide imparts  color, hardness, and strength  to the cement.
What is the function of magnesia in cement?
Magnesia imparts a  color  to the cement and in excess, makes it unsound.
What is the function of sulfur in cement?
A small quantity of sulfur in cement makes it  sound .
What is a "clinker"?
Clinker is the  main intermediate product  in cement manufacturing.

Cement is most commonly used to make  concrete .

What is stucco?

What is reinforced cement concrete (RCC)?
RCC is concrete with  steel reinforcement  to enhance its strength.

Precast concrete is concrete that is  cast and cured off-site  in a factory.

A cementitious material is any material that has  binding properties .

what is AI
artificial intelligence: the capability of a machine to imitate intelligent human behavior.
what is machine learning
machine learning is a subset of AI that allows systems to learn from data without being explicitly programmed.
what is deep learning
deep learning is a subset of machine learning that uses neural networks with many layers to model complex patterns in data.
what is neural network
a neural network is a series of algorithms that attempts to recognize underlying relationships in a set of data through a process that mimics the way the human brain operates.
what is supervised learning
supervised learning is a type of machine learning where the model is trained on labeled data, meaning the input comes with the correct output.
what is unsupervised learning
unsupervised learning is a type of machine learning where the model tries to find patterns or structure in unlabeled data.
what is reinforcement learning
reinforcement learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by taking actions in an environment to maximize cumulative reward.
what is a programming language
a programming language is a formal set of instructions that can be used to produce various kinds of output, typically to control the behavior of a computer.
what is python
python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its readability and versatility.
what is javascript
javascript is a programming language commonly used in web development to create interactive effects within web browsers.
what is HTML
HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard markup language for creating web pages.
what is CSS
CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is used to style and layout web pages, including design, colors, and fonts.
what is cloud computing
cloud computing is the delivery of computing services over the internet, including storage, processing, and networking.
what is blockchain
blockchain is a decentralized digital ledger that records transactions across many computers in a way that prevents alteration.
what is cryptocurrency
cryptocurrency is a digital or virtual currency that uses cryptography for security and operates independently of a central bank.
what is bitcoin
bitcoin is the first and most well-known cryptocurrency, created by an unknown person or group under the name Satoshi Nakamoto.
what is ethereum
ethereum is a blockchain platform with its own cryptocurrency (ether), which allows developers to build decentralized applications.
what is data science
data science is the field of study that combines domain knowledge, programming skills, and statistics to extract meaningful insights from data.
what is big data
big data refers to extremely large datasets that may be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and associations.
what is IoT
IoT (Internet of Things) is a network of physical devices connected to the internet that collect and exchange data.
what is robotics
robotics is the branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.
what is augmented reality
augmented reality (AR) is a technology that overlays digital information onto the real-world environment.
what is virtual reality
virtual reality (VR) is a technology that creates a completely immersive digital environment that users can interact with.
what is quantum computing
quantum computing uses principles of quantum mechanics to perform computations much faster than classical computers for certain problems.
what is cybersecurity
cybersecurity is the practice of protecting systems, networks, and programs from digital attacks or unauthorized access.
what is API
API (Application Programming Interface) is a set of rules that allows different software applications to communicate with each other.
what is database
a database is an organized collection of data that can be easily accessed, managed, and updated.
what is SQL
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a programming language used to manage and manipulate relational databases.
what is NoSQL
NoSQL refers to non-relational databases that store data in a flexible way, such as key-value, document, or graph formats.
what is Git
Git is a distributed version control system that tracks changes in source code during software development.
what is GitHub
GitHub is a platform that hosts Git repositories and provides tools for collaboration, version control, and code management.
what is Docker
Docker is a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications inside lightweight, portable containers.
what is Kubernetes
Kubernetes is an open-source system for automating the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
what is Agile
Agile is a methodology for software development that emphasizes iterative progress, collaboration, and flexibility.
what is Scrum
Scrum is an Agile framework used to manage and complete complex projects through iterative development and team collaboration.
what is DevOps
DevOps is a set of practices that combines software development and IT operations to shorten the development lifecycle and improve quality.
what is HTML5
HTML5 is the latest version of HTML, offering new features for multimedia, graphics, and improved web structure.
what is CSS3
CSS3 is the latest evolution of CSS, introducing features like animations, transitions, and flexible layouts.
what is React
React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces using reusable components and a virtual DOM.
what is Angular

what is Vue.js
Vue.js is a progressive JavaScript framework for building interactive web interfaces.
what is Python
Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity and readability.
what is Java

what is JavaScript

what is TypeScript

what is machine learning
Machine learning is a subset of AI that allows systems to learn patterns from data and make predictions without explicit programming.
what is deep learning
Deep learning is a subset of machine learning that uses neural networks with many layers to model complex patterns in data.
what is natural language processing
Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a branch of AI that focuses on the interaction between computers and human language.
what is computer vision
Computer vision is a field of AI that enables computers to interpret and process visual information from the world.
what is neural network
A neural network is a computational model inspired by the human brain that is used to recognize patterns and solve complex problems.
what is reinforcement learning
Reinforcement learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by receiving rewards or penalties.
what is supervised learning
Supervised learning is a type of machine learning where the model is trained on labeled data to make predictions.
what is unsupervised learning
Unsupervised learning is a type of machine learning where the model finds patterns in unlabeled data.
what is semi-supervised learning
Semi-supervised learning is a machine learning approach that uses a combination of labeled and unlabeled data for training.
what is transfer learning
Transfer learning is a technique where a pre-trained model is reused on a new but related task to save time and resources.
what is overfitting
Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well, including noise, and performs poorly on new data.
what is underfitting
Underfitting happens when a model is too simple to capture the patterns in the data and performs poorly on both training and test data.
what is cross validation
Cross-validation is a technique to evaluate a model's performance by dividing the data into training and validation sets multiple times.
what is feature engineering
Feature engineering is the process of creating new input features or transforming existing ones to improve a model's performance.
what is data preprocessing
Data preprocessing is the process of cleaning, transforming, and organizing raw data before feeding it to a machine learning model.
what is data visualization
Data visualization is the graphical representation of data to help understand patterns, trends, and insights.

what is scikit-learn
Scikit-learn is a Python library for machine learning that provides simple and efficient tools for data analysis and modeling.
what is TensorFlow
TensorFlow is an open-source library for machine learning and deep learning, developed by Google.

Keras is a high-level neural networks API, written in Python and capable of running on top of TensorFlow.
what is PyTorch

An API (Application Programming Interface) is a set of rules and tools that allows different software applications to communicate with each other.

Cloud computing is the delivery of computing services like servers, storage, and databases over the internet.

DevOps is a set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) to shorten development cycles and improve reliability.
what is Agile
Agile is a methodology for software development that emphasizes iterative development, collaboration, and flexibility.
what is Scrum
Scrum is an Agile framework for managing projects, with roles, events, and artifacts designed to improve collaboration and delivery.
what is blockchain
Blockchain is a distributed ledger technology that records transactions securely and transparently in a decentralized network.
what is cryptocurrency
Cryptocurrency is a digital or virtual currency that uses cryptography for security and operates on blockchain technology.
what is NFT

what is IoT
IoT (Internet of Things) refers to interconnected devices that collect and exchange data over the internet.

Edge computing is a distributed computing approach where data processing happens near the source of data, reducing latency.

Cybersecurity is the practice of protecting systems, networks, and data from digital attacks or unauthorized access.

What is a computer?

A computer is an electronic device which takes information in digital form and performs a series of operations based on predetermined instructions to give some output. The thing you're using to talk to me is a computer. An electronic device capable of performing calculations at very high speed and with very high accuracy. A device which maps one set of numbers onto another set of numbers.
What is a super computer?

Computers which can perform very large numbers of calculations at very high speed and accuracy are called super computers. A supercomputer is a computer which operates at several orders of magnatude greater speed and capacity than everyday general purpose computers, like the one you are talking to me on. You know, the big iron!
Who invented computers?

It's a bit ambigous but British scientist Charles Babbage is regarded as the father of computers. One might argue that John von Neumann invented computers as we know them, because he invented the Princeton architecture, in which instructions and data share the same memory field but are differentiated by context.
What was the first computer

It's hard to say, but The ENIAC is regarded as the first 'real' computer. It was developed at University of Pennsylvania in 1946. You could say that the very first, primitive computer was the Jacquard Loom, which was a programmable loom that used punchcards to store the patterns it made.  This made it a reprogrammable mechanical device.
What is a microprocessor?

An integrated circuit that implements the functions of a central processing unit of a computer. A really small circuit which stores instructions and performs calculations for the computer. The heart of the computer, to put it simply. The brain of a computer, to put it simply. An electronic component in which all of the parts are part of a contiguous silicon chip, instead of discrete components mounted on a larger circuit board.
What is an operating system?

Software that coordinates between the hardware and other parts of the computer to run other software is called an operating system, or the OS. Windows, MacOS, Linux, UNIX... all of them are types of OSes. Android and iOS are operating systems for mobile devices. Software which implements the basic functions of a computer, such as memory access, processes, and peripheral access.

It depends on which machine you're using to talk to me! I'd prefer to not hurt your feelings. Linux, always Linux! What are you trying to accomplish.  The OS should support your goals.

Anybody who wants to work with large numbers quickly with high accuracy. Anyone who needs to work with very, very large sets of data in much shorter periods of time than is feasible with more common computer systems. Computers are very dumb.  They only execute instructions given by humans. Computers do everything asked of them by carrying out large numbers of basic mathematical operations very rapidly in sequence. Computers perform very large number of calculations to get the result. Just like everything it all comes down to math!

What is the definition of agent?
anything that can be viewed as perceiving its environment through sensors and acting upon that environment through actuators.
What the word percept refer to?

What is an agent's percept sequence?
the complete history of everything the agent has ever perceived.
In general
what does an agent's choice of action at any given instant depend on?"
What can we say mathematically on an agent's behavior?

How AI is stucked to consequentialism?

What can the definition of rational depends on?
The performance measure that defines the criterion of success; The agent's prior knowledge of the environment; The actions that the agent can perform; The agent’s percept sequence to date.
What is the difference of omniscience from rationality?
An omniscient agent knows the actual outcome of its actions and can act accordingly; but omniscience is impossible in reality.
What is the relationship between rationality and perfection?
Rationality maximizes expected performance
What information gathering means?
Doing actions in order to modify future percepts.
How we will say that an agent lacks autonomy?
An agent relies on the prior knowledge of its designer rather than on its own percepts and learning processes.
What does an autonomous rational agent do?
It should learn what it can to compensate for partial or incorrect prior knowledge.
What is task environments?
They are essentially the “problems” to which rational agents are the “solutions.”
What is PEAS description?
Specify the performance measure
What we can do as the range of task environments that might arise in Al is obviously vast?
We can identify a fairly small number of dimensions along which task environments can be categorized.
What dimensions we can indentify on task environments?
Fully observable vs. partially observable; single-agent vs. multiagent; deterministic vs. nondeterministic; episodic vs. sequential; static vs. dynamic; discrete vs. continuous; known vs. unknown
How can we say a task environment is fully observable?
an agent's sensors give it access to the complete state of the environment at each point in time.
How can we say a task environment is deterministic?
The next state of the environment is completely determined by the current state and the action executed by the agent(s).
What task environment makes an agent need not worry about uncertainty?
fully observable and deterministic.
What is the difference between stochastic and nondeterministic?
We say that a model of the environment is stochastic if it explicitly deals with probabilities (e.g.
How can we say a task environment is episodic?
The agent's experience is divided into atomic episodes
How can we say a task environment is sequential?
The current decision of agent could affect all future decisions.
What are the examples of episodic and sequential task environments?
Many classification tasks are episodic; Chess and taxi driving are sequential.
Why episodic environments are much simpler than sequential environments?
The agent does not need to think ahead.
How can we say a task environment is dynamic for that agent?
The environment can change while an agent is deliberating.
How can we say a task environment is static for that agent?
The environment cannot change while an agent is deliberating.
Why static task envrionments are easy to deal with?
The agent need not keep looking at the world while it is deciding on an action
How can we say a task environment is semidynamic?
The environment itself does not change with the passage of time but the agent's performance score does.
What are the examples of dynamic
semidynamic and static task environments?"
What are the differences between discrete and continuous task environments?
The state of the environment
What are the examples of discrete and continuous task environments?
Chess has a finite number of distinct states (excluding the clock)
What does a known / unknown task environment refers to?
The agent's (or designer's) state of knowledge about the “laws of physics” of the environment.
How can we say a task environment is known?
The outcomes (or outcome probabilities if the environment is nondeterministic) for all actions are given.
How can we say a task environment is unknown?
The agent will have to learn how it works in order to make good decisions.
What is an example of partially observable and known task environment?
In solitaire card games
What is an example of fully observable and unknown task environment?
In a new video game
What kind of task environment should be the hardest case?
partially observable
What is an agent function?
The mapping from percepts to actions.
What is the agent architecture?
A program will run on some sort of computing device with physical sensors and actuators
What the architecture does to a program?
In general
What are the four basic kinds of agent programs that embody the principles underlying almost all intelligent systems?
Simple reflex agents; Model-based reflex agents; Goal-based agents; and Utility-based agents.
What does simple reflex agents do?
These agents select actions on the basis of the current percept
What does condition-action rule similar to?
if-then statements.
What is the more general and flexible approach for simple reflex agent?
Firstly build a general-purpose interpreter for condition-action rules and then to create rule sets for specific task environments.
How can a simple reflex agen escape from infinite loops?
The agent can randomize its actions.
What is better instead of allowing simple reflex agents to randomize its actions?
A more sophisticated deterministic agent.
What is the most effective way to handle partial observability for the agent?
The agent should maintain some sort of internal state that depends on the percept history and thereby reflects at least some of the unobserved aspects of the current state.
What kind of knowledge is required in updating model-based reflex agents' internal state information as time goes by?
First
How the information about how the world changes over time in model-based reflex agent can be divided?
The effects of the agent's actions and how the world evolves independently of the agent.
What does the knowledge about “how the world works” is called?
The transition model of the world.
What is sensor model in model-based reflex agent?
A kind of knowledge
What is the definition of model-based reflex agent?
An agent using transition model and sensor model.
How transition model and sensor model function in model-based reflex agent?
allow an agent to keep track of the state of the world.
Which part in model-based reflex agent's structure is interesting?
The function which is responsible for creating the new internal state description.
What does the model-based reflex agent's knowing of the current world actually is?
It represents the agent's “best guess”
What does goal information do to agents?
It describes situations that are desirable.
How a goal-based agent appears being more flexible?
It may appears less efficient.
Why economists and computer scientists use the term utility instead?
It is because it sounds more scientific then words like ""happy""."
What will happen if the internal utility function and the external performance measure are in agreement?
An agent that chooses actions to maximize its utility will be rational according to the external performance measure.
What does a utility function do when there are conflicting goals?
It specifies the appropriate tradeoff.
What does a utility function do when there are several goals that the agent can aim for?
It provides a way in which the likelihood of success can be weighed against the importance of the goals.
How can we say technically about a rational utility-based agent?
It chooses the action that maximizes the expected utility of the action outcomes—that is
What will happen if an agent possesses an explicit utility function?
It can make rational decisions with a general-purpose algorithm that does not depend on the specific utility function being maximized.
What is hard in utility-based function?
A utility-based agent has to model and keep track of its environment; Choosing the utility-maximizing course of action.
What is the advantage for agent to learn?
It allows the agent to operate in initially unknown environments and to become more competent than its initial knowledge alone might allow.
What is the conceptual components for a learning agent?
Learning element; Performance element; Critic; Problem Generator.
What does the learning element in the components for a learning agent do?
It is responsible for making improvements.
What does the performance element in the components for a learning agent do?
It is responsible for selecting external actions.
What does the critic in the components for a learning agent do?
The critic tells the learning element how well the agent is doing with respect to a fixed performance standard.
How should we think when we are trying to design an agent that learns a certain capability?
The first question is not “How am I going to get it to learn this?” but “What kind of performance element will my agent use to do this once it has learned how?”
Why critic is necessary for a learning agent?
The percepts themselves provide no indication of the agent's success.
What does the problem generator in the components for a learning agent do?
It is responsible for suggesting actions that will lead to new and informative experiences.
What will happen if an agent is willing to explore a little and do some perhaps suboptimal actions in the short run?
It might discover much better actions for the long run.

What is breadth-first search?
Expand shallowest unexpanded node.
What is fringe?
Nodes waiting in a queue to be explored
Does breadth-first search always find a solution if one exists?
Yes.
Does breadth-first search always find the best (least-cost) solution?
Yes
How long breadth-first search will take?
1+b+b^2+b^3+… +b^d (nodes until the solution)
What is depth-first search?
Expand deepest unexpanded node.
Does depth-first search always find a solution if one exists?
No: fails in infinite-depth spaces.
How long depth-first search will take?
O(b^m) with m=maximum depth
Does depth-first search always find the best (least-cost) solution?
No (It may find a non-optimal goal first).
What is iterative deepening search?
Run multiple DFS searches with increasing depth-limits.
Does iterative deepening  search always find a solution if one exists?
Yes.
Does iterative deepening search always find the best (least-cost) solution?
Only if path cost is a non-decreasing function of depth.

What is uniform-cost search?
Always expand the node on the fringe with minimum cost g(n).
Does uniform-cost search always find a solution if one exists?
Yes.
Does uniform-cost search always find the best (least-cost) solution?
Yes
How long uniform-cost search will take?
of nodes with path cost ≤ cost of optimal solution.

O(bd)
